candidates.title: Comrade Tintin
candidates.content:
Another instalment in my occasional series on publishers' ignorance of their own books. The latest culprit is Methuen, which has sent out a press release announcing the publication this week of Tintin in the Land of the Soviets "for the first time in album format in English". Not so: the English translation of Herg's first Tintin serial was originally published "in album format" as long ago as August 1989. I bought a copy on publication day and still have the receipt.
Methuen claims that "Tintin in the Land of the Soviets represents a particular time in Russian history - but to most readers its appeal will be in the excitement, pace and humour of the adventures of its young hero and his trusty dog Snowy". Actually, first-time readers are more likely to be struck by the amazingly slapdash draughtsmanship and the heavy handed anti-communist propaganda. Herg himself, who drew the serial for a Belgian newspaper in 1929 and 1930, later described it as "a transgression of my youth" and refused to let it appear as a book.
Still, there are one or two cherishable moments - particularly when a party of pipe-smoking, tweed-clad tourists is seen gawping in wonder at a factory which has been cunningly rigged to give the illusion of massive productivity. "Look," Tintin comments sarcastically, "English communists being shown the beauties of Bolshevism." Even then, it seems, the English were famous throughout Europe for their political fellow-travelling.
They still are. The only difference, since the fall of the Berlin Wall, has been that the fellow-travellers are all on the Right. Margaret Thatcher and Norman Lamont lionise General Pinochet, while last week's Sunday Telegraph carried the imploring headline "Come Back Henry Kissinger" over an adulatory review of the old mass-murderer's latest volume of memoirs. Is there no modern Herg who can do justice to this gruesome genuflection?
